abstract.text: The review covers transitions M 0 ↔ M 0 in all neutral-meson systems that can show these weak-interaction transitions, M 0 = K 0 , D 0 , B 0 and B s . The four systems are ideal laboratories for studying the discrete symmetries T and CPT. The properties of time reversal T are discussed in classical and quantum mechanics. T violation in K 0 K 0 transitions has been observed 1970 independent of assuming CPT symmetry by using the Bell-Steinberger unitarity relation. Improvements of this observation are reviewed including the latest results from 2013. They show with high significance that CP violation in K 0 K 0 transitions is only T violation without any CPT violation. Transitions in the other three systems do not show CP violation so far and, therefore, neither T nor CPT violation. The large observed CP violation in B 0 → J/ψK 0 decays is presented to be compatible with only T and no CPT violation, the same for the significant but very small CP violation in decays K 0 → ππ, I = 2.

body_text.text: Introduction

Symmetries have always played an important role in the formulation of basic-physics laws. The theorem of E. Noether [1] relates the symmetry under time transformations t → t + t 0 to energy conservation, under space transformations x → x + x 0 to momentum conservation, and rotations x → R x to the conservation of angular momentum. In relativistic mechanics and electrodynamics, these transformations and their symmetries are combined into Poincaré or Lorentz transformations, including time reversal T (t → −t) and the parity transformation P ( x → − x).

The description of elementary-particle dynamics by quantum mechanics and quantum field theory with three interactions obeys Poincaré and Lorentz symmetry as well, and in addition the symmetry C under the exchange of particles and antiparticles. Around experiments showed that two interactions are fully symmetric and that the weak interaction is only symmetric under Poincaré transformations excluding P and C. These two symmetries are maximally broken, up to 1964 in such a way that CP and T were assumed to be perfect symmetries. Since C, P and CP are described by unitary transformations, strong and electromagnetic interactions conserve the quantum numbers C, P and CP, whereas the weak interaction conserves only the quantum number CP and neither C nor P. The transformations T and CPT are antiunitary; therefore, there exist no conserved quantum numbers for them in any of the three interactions. All three interactions could be assumed to be symmetric under the transformations T and CPT.

In 1964 decays of neutral K mesons into two charged π mesons at very late lifetimes indicated that CP symmetry is broken in either the weak or in a new interaction. Since CP = CP T ×T , the symmetries T or CPT or both had also to be broken. Around 1968 it became clear that CP symmetry is dominantly broken in K 0 K 0 transitions and unmeasurably small in the decay amplitudes. Measurements of all four CP-violating parameters in K 0 → ππ decays and measured limits on CP violation in all other K 0 decays allowed in 1970 to conclude that only T symmetry is significantly violated in K 0 K 0 transitions and that CPT symmetry therein is valid within errors.

The review describes the phenomenology of K 0 K 0 transitions (Section 4) and all essential experimental results (Section 5) up to mid 2014. T violation and validity of CPT have been established with steadily increasing precision between 1970 and 2013. T violation and CPT validity are also reviewed for K 0 → ππ decay amplitudes, as well as searches for T violation in K 0 → π ν amplitudes and in transverse muon polarisation in K → πµν decays (Section 6).

The discoveries of transitions between B 0 and B 0 in 1987, between D 0 and D 0 in 2007, as well as detailed results on B s B s transitions since 2006 led to intense searches for CP, T and CPT violation in also these three neutral-meson systems. Apart from unconfirmed 3 σ indications, there exist only upper limits; all results up to mid 2014 are reported here in section 7.

T violation and the search for CPT violation in B 0 decays are discussed in detail in Section 8. Throughout this review, we use the sign convention pM 0 − qM 0 for the heavier mass eigenstate of the M 0 system (M = K, D, B, B s ) and pM 0 + qM 0 for the lighter mass eigenstate. The quantity (|p/q| − 1)/2 is called Re , even if it should be Re /(1 + | | 2 ), i. e. both Re and the unobservable Im are approximated to be 1. Two further conventions used areh = c = 1.
Prehistory

The first identified meson was a positive Kaon with a mass of (500 ± 60) MeV, found in 1944 by L. Leprince-Ringuet and M. Lhéritier [2] in cosmic-ray observations using a triggered cloud chamber, three years before the discovery of the charged π meson [3]. The first observation of a neutral Kaon was reported by G. D. Rochester and C. C. Butler [4], again using cosmic-ray events in a cloud chamber. With the advance of experiments at proton accelerators after 1950, a puzzle appeared when comparing π + , π 0 , π − with masses around 140 MeV, and K + , K 0 , K − with masses around 500 MeV. The heavier mesons were called θ when decaying into two and τ when decaying into three pions. All these mesons were produced with comparably large rates in proton-proton collisions, and with the exception of the π 0 they decayed with comparably long lifetimes. Since the lightest charged meson cannot decay by strong interactions, its lifetime was understood to be similar to that of the muon owing to weak interactions. Puzzling was the observation that the K mesons also decayed with long weak-interaction lifetimes in spite of their abundant production by strong interactions; strong-interaction decays with very short lifetimes into two or three pions are not forbidden by conservation of energy and momentum. The solutions of the puzzle were found around 1953 by A. Pais, M. Gell-Mann and K. Nishijima by introducing the concept of "associated production" [5], e. g. pp → ppK + K − , and of the quantum number "strangeness" [6,7], e. g. S(K + ) = +1, S(K − ) = −1, which is conserved in strong and violated in weak interactions. An important step in 1953 was the discovery that θ + and τ + are identical, also θ 0 and τ 0 , thanks to the invention of the Dalitz plot [8] demonstrating that the three-pion state in τ + decays had spin J = 0. Parity conservation led to J P = 0 − for the τ + and J P = 0 + for the θ + , but the τ and θ masses were equal and also their lifetimes. The increasing number of observed τ and θ decays led T. D. Lee and C. N. Yang [9] to the hypothesis in 1956 that parity symmetry is broken in weak interactions. This was quickly confirmed by two experiments at Columbia University on 15 January 1957, that of L. M. Lederman's group [10] in the decay chain π + → µ + ν → (e + νν)ν and that of C. S. Wu et al [11] in β decays of polarized 60 Co nuclei. Neutral Kaons have a second very strange property, a nonexponential decay law, predicted in 1955 by M. Gell-Mann and A. Pais [12]. Starting from the dominant decay K 0 → π + π − and its known rate Γ 1 , they argued that C symmetry (charge conjugation) requires the existence of the K 0 meson and the decay K 0 → π + π − with the same rate Γ 1 . Transitions K 0 ↔ ππ ↔ K 0 with virtual ππ pairs should then occur with a transition rate comparable to Γ 1 , and all linear superpositions

Neutral Kaons produced in the state K 0 , e. g. in the reaction np → ppK 0 K − , have a non-exponential decay law, decaying dominantly into ππ at early times with a rate Γ 1 and later into the other modes with Γ 2 Γ 1 . This remarkably early prediction turned out to be true in spite of the fact that together with P symmetry also C symmetry is broken in weak interactions. Soon after establishing that P is maximally violated, L. Landau [14] found that C symmetry is maximally violated as well and that the combined symmetry CP is unbroken in weak interactions. For the two neutral Kaon states, which are both P eigenstates with P = −1, CP symmetry implies C symmetry, and the arguments of Gell-Mann and Pais remain unchanged.

In 1956 the group of L. M. Lederman [15] observed 20 K 0 decays into charged final states incompatible with π + π − , living much longer and indicating K 0 2 states with Γ 2 /Γ 1 < 0.10. In 1958 M. Baldo-Ceolin et al. [16] reported a nuclear-emulsion experiment in a K + beam, where K 0 mesons with S = +1 from a charge-exchange reaction such as K + n → K 0 p produced Λ hyperons with S = −1 in a reaction such as K 0 p → Λπ + . This was one of the first clear demonstrations of the transition K 0 → K 0 . In 1961 R. H. Good et al. [17] further investigated this transition by passing a neutral Kaon beam far from its production target through a metal plate and observing the time dependence of K → π + π − decays closely behind the plate. Owing to the two-state nature of neutral Kaons, the time-dependent transitions K 0 ↔ K 0 cannot be described by a single "transition rate". There are two coherent contributions, the mass and width differences ∆m = m(K 0 2 ) − m(K 0 1 ) and ∆Γ = Γ 2 − Γ 1 , as described in detail in Section 4. In addition to |∆Γ| ≈ 0.9 × Γ 1 from Ref. [15], the metal-plate "regeneration" experiment [17] determined |∆m| = (0.8 ± 0.2) × Γ 1 , so both contributions to the transition rate are indeed of order Γ 1 as predicted by Gell-Mann and Pais [12].

Regeneration will be discussed in Section 5.2. Studying these transitions K 0 2 → K 0 1 in matter, the group of R. Adair [18] found an effect in 1963 which they called "anomalous regeneration". At the limit of significance, a larger rate of π + π − decays was observed in a beam of neutral Kaons behind a liquidhydrogen regenerator than that expected from the estimated regeneration rate. The more precise and famous experiment of J. H. Christenson, J. W. Cronin, V. L. Fitch and R. Turlay [19] discovered one year later with high significance that this larger rate occurs also in a near-to-vacuum material, gaseous helium. The influence of regeneration was negligible; long-living Kaons in the assumed CP eigenstate K 0 2 with CP = −1 decayed into the final state π + π − with CP = +1. This evident non-conservation of CP symmetry could still have two origins: the decay dynamics of K 0 2 → ππ or the transition dynamics of K 0 ↔ K 0 generating a long-living state which is not a CP eigenstate. In 1967 the experiment of J. Steinberger's group [20] gave the answer that the second origin is dominating, by observing that the decay rate of the long-living state into π − e + ν is larger than that into π + e − ν.

The first observed meson was a K + in 1944, its neutral partner and the charged pion were discovered in 1947, K 0 K 0 transitions were predicted in 1955 and observed since 1956, the study of K + → π + π + π − decays in 1954 led to the discovery of P violation, and the 1964 observation of long-living neutral Kaons decaying into π + π − was the discovery of CP violation. In the following years, we had the obligation to find out experimentally if CPT symmetry is also broken, more specific: what are the contributions of T and of CPT violation to the observed CP violation in K 0 K 0 transitions?
The Symmetries T and CPT

The concept of time reversal in the basic laws of Nature is different from that of the "arrow of time", both in classical and in quantum physics. The omnipresent arrow of time is a consequence of causality and of entropy increase in closed systems. We only get older and never get younger, and we can never influence an event in the past. However, a basic law can be either time-reversal (T) symmetric or T violating, even if obeying causality and increasing entropy in both cases. The dynamics of weak interactions can be T symmetric or T violating, but in both cases an ensemble of unstable particles shows the arrow of time by becoming a different ensemble composed of surviving particles and various decay states.

body_text.text: The J/ψ meson has been discovered in 1974 in two experiments, in the production reaction p + N → J/ψ + X, J/ψ → e + e − [32] and in the formation reaction e + e − → J/ψ [33]. The decay rate Γ = Γ tot (J/ψ) × B(J/ψ → e + e − ) and the formation cross section σ = σ(e + e − → J/ψ) are given by the same matrix element if T symmetry holds. A measurement of Γ then predicts the formation cross section σ. However, establishing motion-reversal symmetry by the two measurements would not be a test of T symmetry since CPT symmetry predicts exactly the same relation between Γ and σ.

CPT Symmetry

The transformation CPT is the product of the three symmetry transformations C, P and T, interchanging particles and antiparticles, x and − x, t and −t, respectively. Pauli [39] shows that local field theories with Lorentz invariance strictly obey CPT symmetry. Since it is not clear by how much the conditions of Lorentz invariance and locality are valid in e. g. string theory or quantized gravity, all experimental efforts for searching small deviations from CPT symmetry are legitimate and well motivated as they explore uncharted territory.

Outlook and Conclusions

The lack of observing any violation of CPT symmetry is linked to all other successes of quantum field theory in which the CPT theorem [38,39] follows from very basic principles. CPT-violating effects could occur if quarks or leptons are not point-like or if Lorentz invariance is broken, e. g. owing to the appearance of Lorentz tensors [134]. Motivated by the arguments of V. A. Kostelecký [134], BABAR [135] has searched for a special breakdown of Lorentz invariance by allowing a time-dependent variation of the CPT-violating parameter δ in B 0 B 0 transitions according to z = −2δ = z 0 + z 1 × cos(Ωt sid + Φ) ,

where Ω describes the earth's rotation in the galactic frame and t sid is the sidereal time. Fits to the dilepton asymmetry in Eq. 187 give results for z 0 and z 1 which deviate slightly from zero. The significance of the deviation is, however, smaller than 3 σ. No T violation has been observed in strong and electromagnetic interactions. In weak interactions, T violation is well established. In 1970, it has been observed in K 0 K 0 transitions by using unitarity and the existing CP-violation results and limits in all K 0 decay modes; Re (K 0 ) = (1.68 ± 0.30) 10 −3 , Eq. 117. This Bell-Steinbergerv unitarity analysis has been repeated many times until recently. Today's best result is Re (K 0 ) = (1.611±0.005) 10 −3 , Eq. 137. The result has been confirmed in 1998 by a direct motion-reversal observation, comparing the rates of K 0 → K 0 and K 0 → K 0 , independent of unitarity but assuming CPT symmetry in the semileptonic K 0 decay amplitudes, Re (K 0 ) = (1.55 ± 0.42) 10 −3 , Eq. 127. No T violation has been observed in D 0 D 0 , B 0 B 0 and B s B s transitions, but there are good prospects that the experiments LHCb and Belle-II will reach a sensitivity on Re (B 0 ) on the level of the expected Standard-Model T violation, Eq. 185. T violation has also been observed in weak decay amplitudes: T is violated in K 0 → ππ, I = 2 decays, where the phase of / 0 is incompatible with T symmetry as shown in Fig. 11. And T is violated in B 0 → J/ψ K 0 decays, observed in 2001 since the CP-violating parameter λ f in these decays is also T-violating, see Section 8.2. Entanglement of B 0 and B 0 states in Υ(4S) decays allowed a direct demonstration of motion-reversal violation with these decays one decade later, see Section 8.4.

No CPT violation has been observed, but future experiments with neutral-meson systems have the duty to test CPT symmetry with ever increasing precision. Nature may neither have point-like quarks and leptons nor fully Lorentz-invariant couplings of them to vector and scalar fields.
